utterances: We have one more question here.
It's about the rest of the world.
Hi, this is Josh Eisenberg from Carlisle, Pa.
And I was wondering what other countries do censuses, or is it censi (ph)?
(Laughter) I like the Latin there.
Yeah.
Many countries do have decennial censuses as we do.
The United Kingdom does.
Mexico does.
By the way, the earliest census was the Babylonians in 3800 B.C.
And then there's the Gospel writer Luke's nativity story of a census by Caesar Augustus, but I hate to tell you this, Steve.
That one's been called into all kinds of historical question.
Cokie Roberts, thanks very much.
Always good to talk to you, Steve.
You can ask Cokie your questions about how politics and the government work by tweeting us with the hashtag, #AskCokie.
Every Tuesday until the election, we're featuring stories about the political races in the West.
One of the most competitive House matches this year is in Colorado's 7th District.
That's in the Denver suburbs.
Four years ago, Republican Bob Beauprez won a narrow victory in that district.
Now, he's trying to hold on to his seat as his constituents express their growing concerns about the about the Iraq war.
From Denver, NPR's Jeff Brady reports.
Colorado politics are changing.
Just a few years ago, the state was a Republican stronghold.
Then in 2004, Democrats took control of the state legislature, as well as the U.S.
House and Senate seat - not because there are more Democrats in Colorado, but because more unaffiliated voters chose Democratic candidates.
It's not a surprise then that unaffiliated voters are the focus for Democrat Ed Perlmutter and Republican Rick O'Donnell in the 7th Congressional district.
Both are spending a lot of time walking through the fallen leaves in neighborhoods outside Denver.
(Soundbite of footfalls)
Perlmutter is in Lakewood with a list of houses to visit.
D's and U's, he says - a few Democrats, but mostly unaffiliated voters.
(Soundbite of knocking)
(AUDIENCE LAUGHTER)
I'm Ed Perlmutter.
I'm running for Congress.
How are you?
Hello.
I'm good.
Perlmutter starts talking about education funding.
That's important, says Millbratt.
But to her, the war is the big issue, and she ignores her ringing phone to explain why.
I just lost a second cousin's grandson over there in Iraq in June - 21 years old, married, a little baby.
Bad situation, and no reason for it.
We shouldn't be there.
Both Democrat Perlmutter and Republican Rick O'Donnell are critical of the handling of the war.
Each has called on Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld to resign.
At a forum, the two were asked what they think should happen next in Iraq.
While the debate is often framed as stay-the-course versus cut-and-run, in this district, the candidates' views are more nuanced.
Perlmutter says the U.S.
should hand over security to Iraqis as soon as possible, then lay out a multinational reconstruction effort.
And finallyâ€¦

Third, re-deploy some of our troops to nearby bases in the event a quick strike is necessary somewhere back in the region, and complete all of that by the spring of '08, in which case we'll have been in Iraq for five years.
The candidates disagree on two big issues related to the war: if a deadline for troop withdrawal should be set, and whether more soldiers are needed in the meantime to establish control.
Republican O'Donnell is open to sending more troops to Iraq, but is flat out against a date certain for withdrawal.
Mr.
RICK O'DONNELL (7th Congressional District Republican Candidate, Denver): That is just setting an arbitrary deadline rather than focusing on what's our goal.
Our goal should be, as quickly as possible, to provide a safe, secure country that can take over for itself.
And I hope we can do it before the spring of 2008.
The war is a difficult issue for O'Donnell, as it is with most Republican candidates.
He doesn't bring it up voluntarily, preferring instead to focus on immigration and the economy.
Even though he's distanced himself a bit from the president, he's relied on members of the administration for fundraising.
Political analyst Floyd Ciruli says unaffiliated voters will decide this election.
And right now, he says, they're leaning toward the Democrat.
They're more subject to the national tide because they're less anchored in a party.
They're less anchored into consistent voting pattern.
And the tide right now is just overwhelmingly hostile to the Republican Party.
Ciruli says this district is unpredictable.
In 2004, the majority voted for John Kerry as president, but overwhelmingly selected an incumbent Republican for Congress.
Just about the only thing he can predict is that the race is going to be close.
Jeff Brady, NPR News, Denver.
(Soundbite of music)
You can follow our month-long series of reports on issues and races important to Western voters at our Web site, npr.org.
Stay with us on DAY TO DAY, from NPR News.
Former White House adviser Steve Bannon is speaking in Hong Kong today.
He's going to be at an event hosted by an arm of the largest state-owned Chinese brokerage firm.
Bannon, who left the White House just three weeks ago, has been a vocal critic of China's economic policies.
And for more on this, let's bring in NPR's Shanghai correspondent, Rob Schmitz.
Hey there, Rob.
Good morning, David.
So what's Steve Bannon doing in Hong Kong?
Yeah, the title of his speech is broken into three parts - American economic nationalism, the popular revolt, and Asia.
OK.
Each one of those items is a pretty big topic.
So it's unclear what exactly Bannon is going to talk about.
And it was announced this morning that the speech will be closed to the press.
So that'll make it even harder to find out after it's over.
But what we do know is who Bannon will be talking to, and it's going to be an auditorium full of bankers who have made their fortunes on the rise of China.
Which makes this whole thing kind of odd, right?
I mean, doesn't Bannon blame China for hurting Americans, for putting middle-class Americans out of work, for doing a lot of other things?
Yeah, and, you know, here's the thing.
This past weekend, Bannon gave interviews to The New York Times and ""60 Minutes"" as perhaps a sort of preview of this event in Hong Kong.
In The Times, he compared China's rise to that of Nazi Germany.
He told the reporter that in a hundred years we'll all look back to see what we did to confront China on its rise to world domination.
And then on ""60 Minutes,"" here's what he told Charlie Rose.
(SOUNDBITE OF TV SHOW, ""60 MINUTES"")
We're not at economic war with China.
China's at economic war with us.
OK?
You want a trade-war with China?
I want China to stop appropriating our technology.
China is - through forced technology transfer and through stealing our technology, but really forced technology transfer - is cutting out the beating heart of American innovation.
OK, Rob Schmitz, I'm still trying to figure this out.
So - so if Bannon is basically trashing China and saying that China is up to no good, why would a branch of a big, state-owned brokerage firm want to hear a speech from him?
Why bring him?
Yeah, it's counterintuitive.
Well, you know, first off, this event, sponsored by a firm called CLSA, is an annual one.
And in previous years, they brought in other controversial speakers like Edward Snowden and Sarah Palin.
It's also important to point out here that CLSA makes its own decisions and is largely left alone by its parent company.
So there's that.
But perhaps most importantly, no other U.S.
president in modern history has been as difficult for the Chinese to read as Donald Trump has been.
And the organizers probably think that Bannon will help shed some light on what's going on behind the scenes in the White House.
The audience, of course, will be full of bankers so they're going to want to know whether Trump is serious about, for example, putting sanctions on Chinese companies who do business in North Korea.
They're going to want to know how Trump really sees China and if his relationship with Chinese President Xi Jinping is a positive one.
Secretary Geithner talking on CNBC on Monday to walk us through the week.
We are joined by our regular political commentators - E.J.
Dionne of the Washington Post and the Brookings Institution, and David Brooks of the New York Times, welcome.
Mr.
E.J.
DIONNE (Political Commentator, Washington Post and Brookings Institution): Thank you.
Thank you.
